ğ“„Ÿğ“‚“ğ“„› Õ´Õ¡Õ·Õ¯, Õ¯Õ¡Õ· maÅ¡k kaÅ¡i [[ğ’‹¢]] KUÅš:skins Ñ†É™Ğ° áƒ™áƒáƒœáƒ˜ askÉ‘ni skin masker > ğ“‚“ğ“„› Õ¯Õ¥Õ²Õ¥Ö‚ kÉ›ÊÉ›v < dÃ§er ğ“†“ğ“›ğ“‚‹ğ“„œ  

ğ“Œ• â‹ ğ’ â‹ ğ’— â‹ [[ğ’Œ€]] â‹ [[ğ’‹¾]] TIL tilâ‚ƒ tÃ®r (Alternative forms)  
[[ğ“Œ•]][[ğ“„œ]][[ğ“„]] Î¶oo.tÃ®r ğ’‰¼ tir à¦¤à§€à¦° tÄ«r â‡”  shooter ğ“‹´ ğ“„ ğ“ ğ“Œ•  

By the end of the Old Kingdom, the classifier was suddenly extended to the classification of living animals that â€œhave (?) hide & tailâ€. Starting with the lion.  

In the Middle Kingdom, the extension into the â€œanimateâ€ animals became a clear tendency in the script, with dog, cat, mouse, as well hippo and pig, getting the , and being all recorded also in lapidary hieroglyphic inscriptions as well as in cursive script and hieratic.  
The category is extended by the new Kingdom to include many members that have no hide or no tail, or both, such as frogs. clear examples are the scorpion or the **tur**tle.  

the egyptian script system always keeps the parallel option to classify an animal by _repeater_ (silent/specifying determinant) or unique, or both by repeater and the generic hide &tail.  

 By the end of the new Kingdom it seems that the generic category hide & tail starts to be further extended, to occasionally include also birds â€“ thus moving towards the higher generic concept animal.

However When the Bible is translated into coptic, the egyptians resort to using a greek loanword â€“ â€œzá½¡oÎ½â€.
